Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Use of Institutional Data to Identify Predictors of STEM Degree Completion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: Hispanics are now the largest minority group enrolling at four-year colleges and universities; however, degree completion rates remain lower than among non-Hispanic White and Asian Americans. Student persistence and success in pursuit of undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields are not well-predicted simply by prior academic preparation and test scores, and furthermore, those experiences or qualities which enhance retention may differ both across racial or ethnic groups, and across disciplines. This study develops highly detailed institutional data from a large Hispanic-Serving public university with a substantial population of historically underrepresented minorities. These data have potential to detect possible differences by race/ethnicity in the relative importance of various factors in student intentions, retention, and completion of STEM degree programs.

This pilot project explores the potential for using existing, large-scale institutional data at the university level to identify factors that may contribute to greater participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. Large-scale analytic datasets including such diverse data on pre-college preparation, financial aid, course enrollments and completions, and demographics of students and faculty are rare. This project will extract, combine, and recode student- and course-related information from multiple data sources to produce new longitudinal, student-level analytic data files, permitting examination of how student characteristics, course preparation and sequencing, and instructional environments interact to facilitate STEM degree completion. Exploratory descriptive analyses utilizing the new analytic files will assess feasibility and appropriateness of applying more sophisticated econometric modeling and simulation-based approaches, towards identifying and evaluating policy interventions to increase participation of underrepresented minorities in the STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, “EAGER: The Use of Institutional Data to Identify Predictors of STEM Degree Completion,” explored feasibility of combining existing, institutional administrative datasets from a large public university, to identify predictors of undergraduate students’ persistence, and completion of degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Our exploratory descriptive analyses using the created analytic files evaluated their usefulness for assessing differences in student interest, persistence, and completion of STEM degrees across Hispanic, lower-income, and first-generation college student groups.

Using admissions records, we extracted student-level information such as student gender, race/ethnicity, high school attended, first-time full-time undergraduate status, transfer credits and branch campus attendance, standardized test scores, and Pell grant eligibility. These data were merged with registration event data including the student’s course enrollments, declared majors and programs of study, and whether the student successfully completed a bachelor’s degree, including the semester in which each of these events occurred. Finally, linking course-level instructor IDs to human resources data with faculty gender and race/ethnicity, we were able to observe for each student-course pair whether the student’s instructor was of the same gender or race/ethnicity as the student.

Our completed analytic dataset includes observations on over 12 thousand undergraduates admitted between 2006 and 2011, who attempted at least two STEM courses in biology, chemistry, physics, or calculus, as required of intended majors in STEM fields. We consider these students as intended or prospective STEM majors. For the 2006 admissions year, half of these prospective or intended STEM majors identified as non-Hispanic white, and just over one-third as Hispanic. By 2010, the shares of these two groups among prospective/intended STEM majors were equal, at 42%. However, 6-year graduation rates were 3 percentage points lower for Hispanic students in this group, and 4-year graduation rates were 6 percentage points lower. Among prospective/intended STEM majors who did earn bachelor’s degrees, 42% of non-Hispanic white students earned their degree in some STEM field, versus less than 37% of Hispanic students.

Within these data, we find sufficient useful variation in student characteristics and class environments to examine students’ outcomes with respect to the key STEM course sequences in calculus and in general chemistry, including lab sections. These detailed data also provide opportunities to test hypotheses from smaller-scale studies examining alternative pathways to STEM degree completion—for example, transfers from community college to 4-year institutions—and more detailed modeling of student choices across specific STEM fields or disciplines.
